Well, here in New York lawmakers want to make it illegal to look at your phone while crossing the street and find people up to $250. If the bill passes, New York would become the first state to put in place that kind of ban. Do we like this or not?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Well, put it this way since 2009, 46 - pedestrian deaths have gone up 46 percent. Two reasons. Pot and texting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You know that--

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: And people are high--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: People are high and texting, one or the other. Maybe at the same time.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Exactly. I'm just telling you it's not a coincidence. And I just don't think - you're going to find people for everything these days, but they're trying to do in six other states. They tried it in Honolulu, and they said that things didn't change.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. I don't know if this type of fine is going to change behavior. Do you agree?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I don't know, I don't like to be hyper regulated. However, I did almost see somebody die this way and luckily, she was doing this, and she had her headphones in.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Is that you right there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That was you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So, she had her headphones in, and she didn't - she was just stepped right out, and this guy grabbed her by the back of the jacket and yanked her back just in time. And I also, eight years ago when I first moved here, walking and doing the same thing and I almost fell down the steps of a subway entrance and learned my lesson and I don't do it anymore.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: That's the first time you took the subway.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We kind of do like people texting while walking, because it gives us this great video clips, Juan don't you agree?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, I'm stunned. In fact, last week, I think I mentioned you guys that I'm walking down the street and I started counting how many people are actually walking versus either talking on the phone or texting on the phone. Some of them may be just reading the phone, but it's the clear majority walking down in New York City street. It's crazy and then you come to the intersection. Now my problem is what was cited earlier, I don't think this is the role for the government. I don't want him telling people what they can do and can't do. I think we're in the midst of a cultural shift. Parents should say something to the young people. I think schools have to educate people in terms of how they deal with social media. But right now, people don't know how to handle it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, because I used to walk down the street and people used to just get out of my way.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Not anymore.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Now, they don't see me, they're walking right into me.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think honestly walking on the streets it's like mad mean trying to - and it makes you who is paying attention have to do the like and left and right and whatever because the person on their phone is just not carrying.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, it upsets the social hierarchy when people don't know who to get out of the way for. It messes with everyone.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: By the way, those cities that tried to do before, Honolulu's fine is a tiered fine system. It just started at $15, so I think that's partly why the deterrence didn't work. But in Montclair in California, the first offense was $100. So, I also think that the level of fine that you would have--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think that also you find people because it's actually - it's - if you get hit by some - you don't want individuals to get hurt but also, I don't want to hit you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And then is my problem.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Yes, exactly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I don't want that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's why I would find them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Finally Brooks (ph) doesn't kiss and then play golf. He apparently was so laser focused that he ignored his girlfriend's attempts to give him a good luck kiss before the final round of the PGA Championships. Don't worry though, he later made up for the diss after winning the tournament. Brian--

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Totally get it. It's before the tournament. The guy's got a lock down the PGA Championship, you can't be making out with people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's not a make out, maybe just receiving a peck.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: It could escalate.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It could have escalated like a full on make out session on the way to the tournament.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: He would have put back to her.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I wouldn't blame the kiss, right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He didn't look happy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: After the diss.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It was funny how she tried to play it off Juan like it never happened.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't know. You know to me I think public displays of affection; I don't think that was the place for it. And clearly, she didn't get it. You know he's focused.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I blame her for trying to go for the kiss.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Always blaming women.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm saying, don't kiss her before I come on set of THE FIVE.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: I agree with that though. Like no role. It is not about you and I feel like she keeps thinking it is, which is probably why that photo after with a trophy like that is all for her Insta. If you are the pro-athlete and you're 30 seconds before game time like you sit, do not even talk to him. I feel like that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: At least she didn't text and then just walk into him and trip him. Or high.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Maybe she was.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Up next, One More Thing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Time now for One More Thing. Listen up Massachusetts, a 3-year-old former police dog in your state is looking for a loving new home after losing one of his legs to cancer. He forced his retirement from the force. His name is Blue. He's a former canine bloodhound. He was a prize member of the Billerica Police Department for over two years. So, he's diagnosed last month because they felt this little troublesome growth and it turned out it was a soft tissue tumor. Blue was taken in by the Massachusetts Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals where he's already as you can see making some big strides, but he's waiting to find his forever home. So, you can check our Facebook page. We'll have more on that. And also, in the spirit of recovery and giving back, I wanted to mention Mercy Ships. That's an organization of course I talk about it a lot. They are looking for some volunteers and if you want a life-changing experience, they need all sorts of people, go to their website. mercyships.org and in media relations, they need a captain, they're looking for engineers as well as nursing staff. Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Jesse's taxi tales, are you guys ready for this one.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK. Sometimes taxi drivers graphic - I'm not driving the taxi.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: You're not even in the front or the wind shield.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. That's crazy. So, I lost my wallet and my phone in the backseat of a taxi and I called the phone an hour later. Guy picks, he's all the way in Queens. They drive the taxi all the way back to Manhattan and deliver me my phone.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Did you tip him well?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, they charge me for the trip, but I mean I did throw a really fat tip. Can you believe that? I mean these guys are so honest and so nice. I Uber New York City taxi. It's a tossup.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm going for the taxi.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm going for taxis. These guys are great.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right, grab your hat Auntie Em. Another tornado's coming folks. It's peak tornado season in the Midwest. So, take a look will you at this video. That video was done by AccuWeather storm chaser Reed Timmer. He shot the storm in Cook County, Nebraska Saturday. Since Friday at least 38 tornadoes have been reported in Kansas, Nebraska and Texas, Saturday. 11 tornadoes alone. Severe weather remains a threat for at least 48 million according to the National Weather Service. By the way, the Mississippi River has been over flood stage for 131 days a record. And Reed Timmer just so you know he was not hurt despite being unable to see his hand as the tornado swallowed him up. That intense weather reminds me of a quote from The Wizard of Oz. We're not in Kansas anymore.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes. And actually, severe weather apparently is still ongoing so make sure you're checking in with your local authorities and doing what you need to do. Brian.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: All right, Dana. This is for the history major, Jesse Watters. If you want to see if you like the series The FOX Nation series What Made America Great, I'm bringing it to the stage, it's going to be in Bonita, Springs; Orlando, Florida; Charlotte, North Carolina; Birmingham, Alabama. So, I'm able to take what we did on Fox Nation the 10 and then also have a chance to talk about George Washington's Secret Six, Thomas Jefferson Tripoli Pirates, Andrew Jackson miracle of New Orleans and the soon to be published if I'm done within the next two and a half weeks. Sam Houston and the Alamo Avengers and I get a chance to interact with everyone, so it's probably the most fun I'll ever have.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And do you make fun of Greg Gutfeld on stage?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: I will not do that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Because he would do that about you.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: I think he is doing it about me according to many sources. Slash tour.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Check it out. Emily.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: All right, you guys, you all know that I love my 1972 Mach 1. Well, she has recently undergone an overhaul so that's her before, this is her after.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: She's already for the 2019 Hot Rod Power Tour, which Fox will be covering. So, you will be able to come along with me and I'm racing in this - I'm participating in that event along to celebrate the debut of this amazing charity, it's called 4vrRIP. It's launching during the Power Tour and it restores the classic cars left behind by those service members and first responders killed in action. So, stay tuned, because I'm going to be burning rubber for a great cause. We'll have drag racing. We're going through five different states. It'll be a really great time.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You're going to be behind the wheel?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's my car.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Fantastic.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Does that comes from your dad or your mom?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: My dad is like super Italian, so he loved cars, but not muscle cars like that. So, I grew up going to car shows with him and whatnot. He had kind of like a different appreciation, different style. And then for some reason I just like love--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You just love it. And you're doing it for a really good cause too.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right, great show. Good way to start the week. Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of "The Five." Content and Programming Copyright 2019 Fox News Network, LLC. utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Emily Compagno, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and Brian Kilmeade. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is "The Five." All right, President Trump and Joe Biden battling in the key battleground state of Pennsylvania. Trump is headed there tonight as he gets ready to officially launch his reelection campaign. But before he rallies, supporters -- Trump -- firing shots at the former vice president on twitter, quote, looks like Bernie Sanders is history. Sleepy Joe Biden is pulling ahead. And think about it, I'm only here because of Sleepy Joe.  And the man who took him off the one percent trash heap, President O.  China wants Sleepy Joe badly. And Biden in Philadelphia this weekend knocking Trump and claiming the Obama administration deserves credit for the booming economy.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, FORMER U.S. VICE PRESIDENT
utterances.utterance: I know President Trump likes to take credit for the economy and the economic growth and the low unemployment numbers, but just look at the facts. Not the alternative facts. President Trump inherited an economy from Obama-Biden administration that was given to him just like he inherited everything else in his life.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. So, Juan, Biden rebranding the Obama administration to the Obama-Biden administration. I'm going to say all as one word now.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, I think it helps him. Especially helps him with black voters, minority voters.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think what struck me, though, is that he is really intent on the idea of saying, you know what? We're not angry. Despite all the talk about Democrats wants to impeach Trump, Democrats are so angry, that defines the Democratic base. Nope, he's saying, you know what? People like the idea that we would return to stability and civil discourse and civil debate. And I think that's a winning ticket. That's not only, I might add, a rebuttal to Trump, I think it's a rebuttal to other Democrats.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Maybe. But, Jesse, do you think that Biden -- you can't go for 16 months and not counter punch.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I mean, he's running on unity. He can't even unify his own party. I think he misreads the American people, this is a rambunctious country. We want entertainment. We're thirsty.  We're hungry. We want action. Restoring the Obama years is not a selling point. One of the reasons Trump was elected is because of Obama-Biden.  You know that whole system didn't work for the forgotten men and women of this country. And that's why Trump came in to shake things up. If you look at -- Biden has been here for 30 years. And now he's going to come around and say, oh, yeah, Trump broke everything in two. I mean, Biden gave us NAFTA. Biden gave us China and the WTO. Biden gave us an economy that wasn't working for people in manufacturing jobs. So I don't think that's going to stick.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And Trump has given us what? Tariffs? Oh --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, you just wait on those tariffs. I'm going to slap one on you in a second.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The interesting dichotomy of both groups, the Democrats and Republicans, fighting over the economy, both sides seem to think that it's very clear to them, if you're a Democrat, you're like, obviously, this great economy is because of all the things Obama did over the years to pull us out of the great recession. And the Trump people are like, well, no, you had eight years to do that, and it took President Trump doing deregulation and tax reform in order to juice the economy.

utterances.speaker: BRIAN KILMEADE, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: You know, a couple of observations --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Permission granted.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Thank you very much. A couple of things, on your question in particular, I would stand on President Obama blaming George Bush for at least 6 years --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Everything.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: -- for the economy and everything else.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Those are the days of decorum and everyone was nice to each other. And then when President Trump takes over he's now doing this for two and a half years, he takes full credit for that. So I'm astounded on what's going on. I do think, Juan, the thing that -- I do like Biden's lines. I think it's well written. It's a nice twist. Even though he says he's coming out unifying and he wants to -- he's not angry. He sounds angry. Every time I hear him deliver, he sounds -- directly he sounds angry. He's sounds ticked off.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Can I play it for people?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Yeah, if you have the VCR.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We have the VCR fired up and you can continue making your point.  Let's listen to it, though.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.utterance: Some really smart folks say Democrats don't want to hear about unity. They say Democrats are so angry that the anger candidate can be the better chance here. She has to win the Democratic nomination. Well, I don't believe it. I really don't. If Democrats -- I believe Democrats wants to unify this nation. That's what our party has always been about.  That's what it's always been about, unity.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: See, that was kind of mellow. The beginning was a little bit harsh. I don't know the answer to this. But Joe Biden came out and flew in the face of every expert who said that once he gets out there, he was going to drop a steady rose. And he did it by not apologizing. He didn't apologize for the crime bill, didn't really apologize for Anita Hill. The touching, he didn't apologize for that. Reparations -- I'm bringing that up. Medicare for all, that won't work. So he flew in the face on everything the Democrats said that they needed to be successful and he rose five points. I don't know the answer to that.  Something is going on. I know we haven't really started yet, but there's something going on. The experts don't really know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think it's pretty clear. But I want Emily to pop --

utterances.speaker: EMILY COMPAGNO, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I think what's going to be interesting is Pennsylvania, specifically, right, where the president is holding his rally tonight. He won that county by almost 23,000 votes in 2016, which is a lot considering that he won the state but less than 70,000. And he's doubling down on his 2016 strategy, right? We learned today that I think the focus of this campaign is gonna be the economy and also immigration. And in that county, specifically, there's a heavy manufacturing presence, and it's also really rural. And so his China and tariffs emphasis will likely really resonate especially with those people with which MAGA resonated in 2016 who felt forgotten. And so it will be interesting to see if Biden kind of, a, flying in the face of what you just said, and then also that almost kind of archaic out of touchness. How that will compete with Trump's strategy --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There was a major policy change that he made today that I wanted to bring up with permission because we're all being polite.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: It's a new era.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And, Juan, I'll mention this to you and then we'll get to Mayor Pete in just a moment. So this is Biden on the Hyde Amendment. Now the Hyde Amendment basically says no taxpayer dollars can go to publicly funded abortions, OK? He is now saying that he would change that. The question was -- I'm glad you said you would commit to abolishing the Hyde Amendment, and Biden says right now it has to be -- it can't stay. That's a pretty big change.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It is a big change. But, again, I think that -- in a moment when you see the pro-life people on the offensive, believing that the changes of the Supreme Court and Trump in the White House is a moment to ban abortion in the country, and you have Alabama passing a bill that even, you know, Pat Robertson and -- by the way, Donald Trump say is --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Too much.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- too extreme. You better believe that right now he has stirred up American women. The question is how much. Because remember, white women voted for Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But right now in the polls, he's lagging even with non-college educated white women. And this issue is about women. So you have now Biden coming out and saying, listen, in fact, I believe that the government should help women in terms of family planning, emergency situations. You know, we're not talking about infanticide and late term abortions.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right. But I'm specifically talking about on the Hyde Amendment, Jesse, he has definitely moved left. And maybe that is partly none to where the party is going?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, the party is going far left on abortion, and that's going to be Biden's problem. He's going to be dragged further to the left on all these issues. And I think it's going to hurt him in the general if he even survives the primary.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's 16 -- 16 months is a long time to be the frontrunner, Brian.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Right. And I guess what Donald Trump is doing. It turns out he wants to run for reelection. He's going to fired up next month. And then it's going to be really difficult. I laughed when Mayor Pete came out and said, I don't really like the tweets. I'm going to ignore the tweets.  Nice try. There's a lot of people ignore the tweets. You can't ignore the tweets. When they come at you and the press asks you about them, you can't ignore it --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I would like to see Mayor Pete's phone when Trump hits with the nickname blow up.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think there might have to be another nickname, though. I don't think --

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Alfred E. Newman, you don't like it?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, I'm not for the nicknames anyway. But if we're talking about nicknames -- I don't feel like it pack enough of a punch.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I also don't think he deserves a better or another nickname. I think he's such a small ball guy. One nickname is fine.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: By the way, Trump's been running forever. Trump is --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, forget officially. He officially launched on inauguration day when he filed with the Federal Election Commission. And he's been running ever since.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But they're going to have a kickoff.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, because they want to fool the media in to covering his rallies.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Hey, that's called marketing. OK. Up next, Kamala Harris plan that would punish companies if they don't pay men and women the same.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Kamala Harris pitching a new plan that punishes large companies in order to close the gender wage gap. The 2020 Democrat says she'll fine employers if they don't pay men and women the same salaries. Companies could be forced to give up 1 percent of their profits for every 1 percent in wage gap. Harris explaining more about her plan earlier, watch.

utterances.speaker: SEN. KAMALA HARRIS, D-CALIF.
utterances.utterance: What I am proposing is we shift the burden. It should not be on that working woman to prove it. It should instead be on that large corporation to prove they're paying people for equal work equally. It's that simple. So it is my intention to correct what has been wrong about the way we have designed the system.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: So this is Kamala's third major policy proposal, by the way.  And Elizabeth Warren has submitted almost double that. And they're both in single digits, so interestingly for as many Democrats may support these kinds of policies, it's failing to build momentum in that way. And, Dana, I want to start with you, do you think that holding companies hostage in this way is effective policy? Will it resonate potentially with Democrats?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Remember, so she's -- with this policy proposal, she is not trying to win a general election, she's trying to win the Democratic primary, or at least trying to climb up a little bit more so that she can remain -- sort of a upper tier contention, even though right now she is down in a single digit. So this poll is very well. I wouldn't say just for Democrats. Like, people like fairness, equality, things like that. But as a conservative, Republicans would say, well, wait. Well, why is the government going to know what I'm paying anybody anyway? So she would set up a commission. Like, I'm not for the government getting into everybody's business on this.  Now the question would be like as woman continue to do better in law schools, in medical schools, et cetera, would the same be true if the reverse happened? Like, what if women were being paid more than men in certain cases? Would the fine and the penalty also be put in place? She doesn't address that.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Great point. Juan, in California where Kamala represents, is from, it has the narrowest wage -- gender wage gap in the country. It's 89 cents to the dollar without that policy. So why do we need that policy now?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, you just said it. It's 89 cents to a dollar. Why wouldn't you want to be paid equally if you're equally prepared, equally --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: It's continuing to close. Like it's --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, yeah. I think it is continuing to close. And I mean it's like, you know, the work force now, I think, is predominantly female for the first time in American history. I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think -- so the market and pressure from people talking about this is actually working.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, it's not just market. I mean, we have things like the Lilly Ledbetter Pay Act. We have other kind of equal pay incentives that have put in place because you hear large complaints. But, again, in terms of the politics, this comes back to the fact that in 2016, I think it was 52 percent of the voters were females. And right now you see people like Kamala Harris saying I want to be the candidate for women in America. She's already proposed, one of the three proposals Emily mentioned, raising pay for teachers. Lot of teacher strikes around the country, predominantly female work force and they feel ignored.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Jesse, isn't this just political pandering?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I think it's headline porn. There's no way this will ever happen and she knows it. She's just trying to get attention and reboot the campaign because she's slipped. I find it funny that the Democrats on abortion say they don't want the government involved in people's private live, but now they want the government involved in people's private business. If you have Jim, OK, the company. Jim is on a sales team, a sales associate, let's call him. That's the title. And he has an MBA. He's been in the business for ten years and he has 50 clients. And then you have Teresa. Now, Teresa has been in the business five years. She doesn't have an MBA and she has 25 clients. Under Kamala's bill, you'd have to pay them the same --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- even though Jim has more clients, more experience, and more talent. That doesn't make any sense. I mean, Dana Perino and I both co-hosts of "The Five," yet she probably makes more a lot more money than I do.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We need to bring this up again.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's level the playing field.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I just want to point out in the break, we were kind of -- I was sounding out this talking point --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, we were saying don't say it on air.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: That Emily has gotten to me last.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: So this is what I would say. I would say a couple of things.  In our business system there's hypocrisy. I mean, for the most part, Diane Sawyer and Barbara Walters, they were the big stars, they got paid more than a guy who might not have a big name. Because if you're bringing ratings, you're bringing advertising, I, to me, I always thought you're growing to get paid. I don't know if it was Katie Couric, or Matt Lauer, the one that's the heavyweight gets paid regardless of gender. Right now they say women get 80 cents on the dollar. Black women get 69 cents on the dollar. Latinos get 62 cents on the dollar. I'd like to see that gap narrow. But I don't know how you find out because these salaries are secret, number one. And number two is, now the situation is they believe -- they're actually trying to find people in noncompliance. They want to raise $180 billion in ten years for companies who aren't in compliance. That's --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So they actually really don't want to solve the problem.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: They wanted to be bad.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Good job, Brian.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You did a good job there.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But here's the thing, so I was reading this week something Elizabeth through a journalist in D.C. And she was talking about how when she was at a good publication with men, the men all got jobs at the New York Times, the Washington Post, and that's where the salaries boom. She never was able to get into that group. And if you talked to people, Barbara Walters included, about their experiences, Brian --

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Seventies.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. They say, hey, listen, you know to be a woman in TV -- oh, especially as you got older, you didn't get paid more. You got the boot.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's a different time. But you talked about women at the top of their career, the big names, right? You're not talking about people who are entry or trying to move up. And I think there is a disparity.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: There's a lot -- I think there's a lot of reasons and factors that go into that disparity that you have to account for from an investment standpoint. So for example, you're not going to have more female attorneys than men until you go back to school and law schools and whatnot. There's an investment that needs to happen in different ways. And I think hamstringing companies is not the right way to account for whatever the back flow is, and especially those qualities that you can't qualify.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And also -- from a free market perspective, competition really does matter, like we're in very a tight job market. Remember was it salesforce.com did that big audit of their own books? And they found out, oh, my gosh, we're not paying women as much. So they worked to make it up to them. Other companies started the say audit. There was a similar company, they actually found out they were paying women more than the men, so then they have to increase those salaries. I do think that the peer pressure from your competitors does help this issue.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And I would like to see Kamala Harris' senate staff salaries numbers to see if she actually is --

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- her men more or less than the women. I know Hillary Clinton when she made a big deal about the gender wage gap actually paid females less than men.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: All right you guys. We have to go. But is Alexandria Ocasio- Cortez next in line to run America's biggest city? The details next.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: It's like someone just broke into the studio.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: It was jarring. Hey, Bill de Blasio is only five days into his pipe dream quest for the White House, but speculation is already swirling about who should succeed the disastrous Democrat as New York City mayor.  The paper floating this, this is the New York Sun, the idea of Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez as being the perfect candidate who were to run for the top job in the city. I'll bring you a quote out of the article and I just rip it on the edges.  I couldn't find a knife. One could imagine that the prospect of mayoral race would look attractive to the young fire brand with a, we don't mind saying, quick wit and taste for lime light. What kind of mayor would AOC be? What do you think, Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, one, I think that this shows an obvious lack of imagination, or total laziness, or they really don't want her to be in the Congress, right?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: So they wanted her --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Like, get her off the stage because she is now the -- besides President Trump, the most popular politician -- no offense to the Biden team. Like, the mayor's office, you have to have executive decision --

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: She's been in Congress for about six months. So I -- like her executive decision making makes Bill de Blasio look like Mike Bloomberg.  And that is why -- I think she should just stay where she is. She's in -- she's in that poll position to -- she could be a king maker.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Right. I find her decisive, confident, charismatic and hard working. Jesse, can you fault me on any of those four qualities I pointed out?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You just want her to run for mayor so you can cover her on Fox & Friends every single day. You know the New York Post would love AOC as mayor.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: And all four things I've said were 100 percent right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You're right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And she's got everything that you've said. But like Dana said, she does not have the technical acumen, the managerial experience to run the city, because the city needs to be run. You can't just tweet about the price of croissants or talk about socialism in theory, because in practice --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- the city has to run smoothly. And in a way, it might be good for her to be mayor because she would run the city so fast into the ground, you definitely get a Republican after the first term.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: We were on automatic pilot right now, Emily. We have a mayor that works out --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The show or the --

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Were we live? At 10 o'clock he works out. At 12 o'clock, he gets to the office. According to the New York Post, lays down in his office with the door open with the newspaper on his head and the city is still running. Why AOC has nothing about a workaholic. She'd be great.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: I hear what you're saying. He's definitely is just like rock bottom. And that's why he has a 18 percent approval rate in the city.  You're right that there's no worse that she can do, especially given the energy bill that the major just passed, which all the buildings have to be like made of seaweed or whatever. Definitely option C. I think it's wishful thinking on the part of the Democrats to remove her from the national stage because she is driving policy and conversation. You guys look at America is, it's the Khloe Kardashian genes line. Bear with me for a second. Basically I get their emails, whatever. And it said --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, I did not know that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm listening.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: It says -- it was like just like hoops and red lipstick go together on AOC, so too does our looks. So basically in all facets of kind of normal life outside of a political sphere, people are referencing her.  She is a goddess to them. And so you're right that it needs to be harnessed in some way, think the Democrats, but they want to contain her. And they're raising, by the way, of saying, oh, she'll probably be fatigued if the Republicans take back over the House in 2020, I think is really infantilizing and kind of lame.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Would your wear those jeans, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, if I could fit in --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, gee, mom jeans for me. But I must say, I think that Dana is on point. I think the rest of you missed it here.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: I agreed with her.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me tell you, Dana is on point. And first, this is a conversation among Republicans in the Sun, people at a dinner party, Upper East Side types, having a conversation, this is not the same electorate.  And the second thing is, guess what? They are thinking, oh, de Blasio hit rock bottom. Then you say, oh, she's going to take us further down.  That's craziness.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Well, she killed the Amazon deal.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I bet she should be better.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think Mike Bloomberg thought that this was great training. I think Rudy Giuliani thought it was great training. You're dealing with national security. You're dealing with a big school system. You're dealing with a large police force. All these issues are there. The question is, does Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez get kicked out, do Republicans regain the House next time around? Does she decide, oh, maybe I should challenge Charles Schumer in New York for the senate seat.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, I know America's mayor and AOC is no America's mayor.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, thank God.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Oh, Rudy -- he paved the roads. We stopped shop lifters, pick pockets --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: -- PG boys.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Show me the pick-pocketer.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what I'm going to use one of Jesse's lines. He opened the door for de Blasio. His policies.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Bloomberg.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm saying that those kinds of harsh policies. Giuliani time in the like. Boy, I tell you it changed the attitude.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think those are the things that clean this.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh! I see. Very good.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Hey listen. I'm pretty sure I'm responsible for bringing in this block and taking us out. You guys stand back. I have to look straight ahead.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: This is a meritocracy.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: All right. Up next, a stunning surprise for some graduates this weekend is some big relief on their college debt.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The graduation ceremony at Morehouse yesterday anything, but ordinary. Class of 2019 at the historically black college getting the surprise of a lifetime from billionaire keynote speaker Robert Smith.

utterances.speaker: ROBERT SMITH, CHAIRMAN, VISTA EQUITY PARTNERS LLC
utterances.utterance: On behalf of the eight generations of my family who have been in this country. We're going to put a little fuel in your bus. My family is making a grant to eliminate their student loans.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow. Smith's generous gift to pay off the student loan debt for nearly 400 graduates may be worth a whopping $40 million, but it raises a bigger question, is the student loan debt crisis so bad that we need to rely on people like Smith. Jesse, what do you say?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I just like watching the guy's face in the corner when he heard he got his debt cleared. That was pretty good. I think it summed it up. It's funny to hear people like politicians that have driven this country into 22 trillion in debt. Lecture everybody else about now they have to solve the problem of debt. Usually, the government creates the problem and then they have to come in and solve it. Also, the press, all these journalists, they're up to their ears in credit card debt and they've been saying it's not a crisis at the border, but we have a President crisis, please. Why don't we just get a bunch of billionaires you know like Bezos, Bill Gates.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Warren Buffet.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Warren Buffett. Maybe they can pony up a few billion to clear the student loan debt. Or how about these universities, they have tons of endowment money. They can do the same thing. Top 10 percent in your class graduates. They can get their student debt cleared or all these great companies. Amazon, great company. Jeff Bezos. He could pony up a few dollars to help.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: But why should he have to though. That's the whole thing. Should he have to.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's for a tax write-off.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: So, we want to go to Michigan or out of state and it's a goal of a lifetime to go to Michigan, it's $72,000. My parents really can't afford it, so I take out a loan as a parent and then the kid takes out a loan and they have a great time and they look around and they get, their first jobs $50,000 and next you know their payments $500, $550 a month and that's after you've already paid your taxes. So, if you make 50,000, you probably take it on 32,000 and then you're paying that much. It's hard to pay for rent, utilities, phone. So maybe it's an impossible equation. That'd be some pushback, so we don't need the billionaire commencement speakers.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Emily, I think Brian reflects something I see which is it's harder for young people these days to go to graduate school, because they say you know I've got to start paying back the debt and I want to take out more money to go to graduate school. It's harder for them than to buy a house and move out of the parent's house slows down a decision to get - it really interferes with growth, I think.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: well, the saddest part about having to make that determination you know do I have a house and stability or a graduate degree. If that's the decision is the fact that it is put in place from pensions and from the bankrupt debacles that every state engages in, the recent tuition is so high is because it is accounting for the pensions of the employees and it's a totally desperate situation. It's not because the value of the education is such and I think what the situation illustrates to me is A, capitalism works. This is a self-made billionaire who is choosing what to do with his 4 billion. He's choosing to extend $40 million in that way in a charitable endeavor and charges those graduates with doing the same with basically saying here you too encompass tenacity and then give back to your community. And if the government were to do it by the way then that's our money. So, for me, I'm like he can do what he wants. That's amazing. But it's an illustration why it should absolutely not be the government that forgives debt and does that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, Dana aren't they lucky they didn't invite me to give that commencement?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That'd be lesson. You can imagine no journalist in the nation and every alumni association probably called their friends.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Wow.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Did you see what--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Robert Smith did.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And in some ways, you know that again talking about that peer pressure and the competition it somewhat works. You remember when Langone paid for all that medical school tuition at NYU. What happened next? John Hopkins figured out a way to do that and it could be the same thing here, which is you know like you think of Bill and Melinda Gates that have done and Warren Buffett, they've done the billionaire challenge like how much will you give away and you make a commitment and you do that. But the thing is Jesse even if there is $1.56 trillion.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's not even close.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: In Student loans. So, there is not enough. And the other problem is the creditors have to be paid. You can't just wipe it out.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Warren wants to just wipe it out.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right. Elizabeth Warren would just say, OK well screw the creditors, like we'll just go ahead and pay this up. I understand. I don't want young people to feel this burden. But you also have the moral hazard. You took out the loan, you should have to pay for it. I do think this is where innovation makes the most sense in two ways, one if you look at Purdue University, where former Governor Mitch Daniels is the President there. He's figured out a way to work with employers in the area that want to hire good people. So, they put him in the pipeline. OK, what you want to hire Emily. She's going to graduate in two years. You're going to put forward 60 percent of her tuition for the next two years, great. You signed a contract. Emily you had to go work there for two years. That might be a good relationship going forward. And then there's also the other thing is companies that are willing to pay for your student loan. Again, type job market. How do you want to attract employees? Are you willing to take on their student loan?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Don't major in women's studies or--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I agree with that too.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Or architecture or you know--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Architecture is good.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Like art history. That's what I mean. Don't major in something you're not going to get a bang--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But I don't know, our history. Like, remember what we say last week.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Jeff Coon.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: $92 million for the Monet that sold the other--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm so glad - excuse me, Mr. Liberal Arts. What did you major?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: History.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Your parents must have been so upset. They said, how will Jesse ever earn?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I didn't major in women's studies.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: I have a hypothetical.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Jesse Watters, a sophomore in college. Fox gets wind in this talented sophomore.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Would they have paid for Jesse's last two years of college.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I doubt it.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: As long as you guaranteed to go work for Fox. Would that have happened, Jesse? And that's the Mitch scenario.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No one recruited me out of college. Let's put it that way.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, for good looks, we would have picked your number one.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I must say at one critical point here. I noticed the Republicans aren't talking about this issue. The Democrats are talking about it. Somebody should talk about it.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: It's a hot issue.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It is a hot issue.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right, coming up, a shocking video of Arnold Schwarzenegger getting kicked in the back. The crackdown meanwhile on texting while walking, I'm all for that and the kiss diss at the PGA Championship. It's gone viral. Next in the Fastest 7 with our number one pick, Jesse Waters.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. Time for the Fastest 7. It's never a good idea to take on the Terminator. Check out this crazy video of Arnold Schwarzenegger getting drop kicked from behind and he barely flinches. Arnold said, he didn't even realize he was kicked until he saw the video and added that he's just glad that the "idiot didn't interrupt his Snapchat". Luckily for the guy the Governator isn't pressing charges. Brian, it's like such a power move to say, I didn't even feel anything.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: But he's got these muscle guys behind him. Huge security guys in - with doing this thing in South Africa and they wouldn't beat the hell out of him. He said I didn't turn around I don't want to get - didn't want to have to get revenge on him. No kidding. That's why you get the muscle guys beating up on him or those--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I mean he really barely moved after he got kicked right there.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, how gracious to say that he's not going to press charges, right. That's pretty impressive.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, how stupid is the kid. I guess I'm just trying to get in the kids--

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: He's trying to get famous.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Or is he thinking this is Mr. Muscles. This is the terminator and I'm going to knock him over and in my mind I'm a fantasy hero.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: And that's why I just want to mention his name or sue him or put him in the lock up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And he didn't even knock him over, which was pretty bad.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what, I don't want people doing that to me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Don't drop kick Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Please.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Leave that to me.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: I just thought he had the perfect response which was with humor and then directing attention to his cause which is Arnold Sports Athletes and he basically said look, don't share that video, show this video.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Up next, we've all seen what can happen if you're texting while walking like this woman falling into a fountain at a mall. Well, here in New York lawmakers want to make it illegal to look at your phone while crossing the street and find people up to $250. If the bill passes, New York would become the first state to put in place that kind of ban. Do we like this or not?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Well, put it this way since 2009, 46 - pedestrian deaths have gone up 46 percent. Two reasons. Pot and texting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know that--

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: And people are high--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: People are high and texting, one or the other. Maybe at the same time.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Exactly. I'm just telling you it's not a coincidence. And I just don't think - you're going to find people for everything these days, but they're trying to do in six other states. They tried it in Honolulu, and they said that things didn't change.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. I don't know if this type of fine is going to change behavior. Do you agree?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know, I don't like to be hyper regulated. However, I did almost see somebody die this way and luckily, she was doing this, and she had her headphones in.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Is that you right there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, she had her headphones in, and she didn't - she was just stepped right out, and this guy grabbed her by the back of the jacket and yanked her back just in time. And I also, eight years ago when I first moved here, walking and doing the same thing and I almost fell down the steps of a subway entrance and learned my lesson and I don't do it anymore.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: That's the first time you took the subway.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We kind of do like people texting while walking, because it gives us this great video clips, Juan don't you agree?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, I'm stunned. In fact, last week, I think I mentioned you guys that I'm walking down the street and I started counting how many people are actually walking versus either talking on the phone or texting on the phone. Some of them may be just reading the phone, but it's the clear majority walking down in New York City street. It's crazy and then you come to the intersection. Now my problem is what was cited earlier, I don't think this is the role for the government. I don't want him telling people what they can do and can't do. I think we're in the midst of a cultural shift. Parents should say something to the young people. I think schools have to educate people in terms of how they deal with social media. But right now, people don't know how to handle it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, because I used to walk down the street and people used to just get out of my way.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Not anymore.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Now, they don't see me, they're walking right into me.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think honestly walking on the streets it's like mad mean trying to - and it makes you who is paying attention have to do the like and left and right and whatever because the person on their phone is just not carrying.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, it upsets the social hierarchy when people don't know who to get out of the way for. It messes with everyone.
